title: Cross-Cultural Professional Communication
description: Navigate cultural differences between Colombian and US professional communication styles

phrases.english: In my culture we..., but I understand here in the US...
phrases.spanish: En mi cultura..., pero entiendo que aquí en Estados Unidos...
phrases.pronunciation: en mee kool-TOO-rah..., PEH-roh en-tee-EN-doh keh ah-KEE en es-TAH-dohs oo-NEE-dohs...

phrases.spanish: Todavía estoy aprendiendo las costumbres americanas
phrases.pronunciation: toh-dah-VEE-ah es-TOY ah-pren-dee-EN-doh lahs kos-TUM-brehs ah-meh-ree-KAH-nahs

phrases.english: Please let me know if I do anything that seems unusual
phrases.spanish: Por favor avíseme si hago algo que parezca inusual
phrases.pronunciation: por fah-VOR ah-VEE-seh-meh see AH-go AL-go keh pah-RES-kah een-oo-soo-AL

culturalNotes.note: Americans typically maintain 2-3 feet of personal space; less physical contact than Colombian culture
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: Colombians stand closer and use more touch (handshakes, pats on shoulder). In US, avoid unless customer initiates

culturalNotes.note: Americans value direct, explicit communication. Say 'no' politely when needed
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: Less indirect than Colombian communication. 'Maybe' or silence is confusing to Americans

culturalNotes.note: Americans view time as valuable commodity. Being late or slow is seen as disrespectful
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: Much stricter time culture than 'hora colombiana'. Punctuality is non-negotiable

culturalNotes.note: US service is friendly but not overly familiar. Use titles (Mr./Mrs.) unless invited to use first names
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: Less formal titles than Colombian 'don/doña' but maintain professional distance

culturalNotes.note: Safe: weather, sports, traffic. Avoid: politics, religion, money, personal life until customer initiates
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: Americans are more private about personal topics than Colombians initially

culturalNotes.note: 15-20% tip expected for good service. Bad service = lower tip, not confrontation
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: More formalized and expected than Colombian propina culture

culturalNotes.note: But they should always be treated with respect. You can politely disagree or set boundaries
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: Similar service mentality but more worker protections through platform policies

culturalNotes.note: Americans prefer direct problem-solving over relationship preservation in service contexts
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: Less emphasis on saving face; focus on solution not smooth social interaction

practicalScenarios.spanishResponse: Gracias por su honestidad directa. Aprecio que me diga exactamente lo que necesita.
practicalScenarios.englishTranslation: Thank you for your direct honesty. I appreciate you telling me exactly what you need.
practicalScenarios.tips: Don't interpret directness as rudeness - it's cultural norm
Respect personal space bubble - don't stand too close or touch unnecessarily

practicalScenarios.spanishResponse: Soy de Colombia. Llevo [X tiempo] trabajando aquí y realmente disfruto conocer a personas de diferentes culturas.
practicalScenarios.englishTranslation: I'm from Colombia. I've been working here for [X time] and I really enjoy meeting people from different cultures.
practicalScenarios.tips: Brief, positive answer. Americans often genuinely interested in immigrant stories
